doc/source/admin/policy.rst.message:
Perhaps combine these two paragraphs to read like this?

"Currently, Designate defaults to the OpenStack legacy "admin" or "owner" scheme for user and identity management. However, like most OpenStack services, Designate also supports a newer Role Based Access Control (RBAC) model using Oslo Policy. An OpenStack library providing support for RBAC policy enforcement across all OpenStack services, Oslo Policy contains two main features, `Keystone Default Roles`_ and `Keystone Scoped Tokens`_. Through the Designate configuration file, you define default RBAC policies in the Designate code. Using a yaml policy file, operators can choose to override one or more features of these policies. (For more information, see :doc:`samples/policy-yaml.)"

The current Designate RBAC is using Oslo Policy. Both the legacy admin/owner and the new "defaults" using the keystone features.
Also, the default RBAC policies are in the code, and cannot be defined through the designate configuration file.
I think the current wording is more clear.

This paragraph (1)"feels" like it should be a note, and (2) perhaps *follow* the paragraph below.

Here's a suggested rewrite:

"NOTE: Starting with the Xena release, Designate enforces Keystone token scopes and default roles, but Olso Policy does not enforce these new scopes and roles by default. However, in the future, it is likely that token scopes and default roles will become the default. For this reason, you might want to enable these configuration settings now to be prepared for the future transition.

Suggestion: make this the first paragraph in this section.

Here's a suggested rewrite:

"This section focuses on two Oslo Policy project configuration settings that control how Designate handles RBAC policies, `enforce_scope <https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.policy/latest/configuration/index.html#oslo_policy.enforce_scope>`_ and `enforce_new_defaults <https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.policy/latest/configuration/index.html#oslo_policy.enforce_new_defaults>`_. You enable these two settings in the Designate configuration file."

Our style guide states:

"Write in the simple present tense as much as possible. ... Use past or future tense only when you cannot use present tense or it does not make sense to use present tense" (p.68).

So, maybe something like?

"When you enable `Keystone Default Roles`_ and `Keystone Scoped Tokens`_ the Designate policy honors the following roles in Desingate:"
Ack

Suggested rewrite of this section:

"Keystone has introduced the concept of `token scopes <https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/admin/tokens-overview.html#authorization-scopes>`_. To ensure backward compatibility, Oslo Policy does not enforce scope validation of tokens by default.

In the Xena release, Designate supports enforcing Keystone token scopes. To enable Keystone token scoping, add the following to your Designate configuration file::

[oslo_policy]
enforce_scope = True

The primary effect of this setting is to allow a system scoped admin token when performing administrative API calls to the Designate API. The Designate API already enforces project scoping in Keystone tokens."

If there can only be one component registry, shouldn't we use a `COMPONENT_REGISTRY.create(zk_client)` method instead?

zuul/zk/components.py.message: As above, it's harmless to have more than one and the current code doesn't prohibit it.

I've revised this to be a create method.  Normally that shouldn't be called more than once, but it will be in the tests because we run multiple components in the same process.  So it doesn't raise an exception if it's called twice (but it also doesn't create a second registry).
Shouldn't this raise an exception if there is already a registry registered?

I'm intrigued by the idea because I also dislike module global variables.  But one of the goals here is to make this work even if we don't have a zk_client.  Example use case: https://review.opendev.org/827935  where if we were to use this, we would change the serialization of the changekey reference based on the cluster model api version.  But the ChangeKey class doesn't interact with zk directly.

We could decide that's a bad idea and drop that goal (and/or pass zk_client around to more objects, but that's about the same as passing around the zkcontext objects this removes).

Or we could merge the two and use my approach with your class method.

But really at the end of the day, it's still a global variable no matter which way we go right?  It's just called COMPONENT_REGISTRY in one version and ComponentRegistry._registries in the other?  Or is there another advantage to storring the registry as a class attribute?

(Also, I'm assuming you meant 'cls._registries' in your example instead of 'self._registries'.)
Yes, it would still be a global state, so fine for me to go ahead with this approach. Yep, that should be `cls._registries`.

I don't mean to be a jerk, but ... I suggest structuring this differently, especially because we know it will have to be refactored once nvme-cli 2.0 is released.

What I mean is, I suggest putting the raise in the else block.  That way what we'll have is:

  parse the error message
  if it's recoverable error 1:
      log debug about show command missing
  elif it's recoverable error 2:
      log debug about nqn couldn't be found
  else
      log debug about unknown error
      raise
  continue processing ...

right now, "recoverable error 2" is the condition exit_code == ENOENT.  When the code is refactored, it will be something like what you are doing to set show_hostnqn_subcmd_missing, and we can slide it in there easily.  And it will be easy to handle other recoverable errors (if we find any).

By the way, I think adding the error message to the debug log, as you do, is a really good idea.  The upstream nvme-cli seems a bit cavalier about changing them, and since they aren't providing an error code in the message, we're stuck parsing the text.  So if we suddenly start getting failures because the message has changed, we'll be able to see it right away.
Done

Should be "if ! [ -a ... ]"? I think putting it inside the brackets causes the check to always pass, which I think doesn't address the prior comments.

ex:
    [ -a /tmp ]; echo $?     # 0
    [ ! -a /tmp ]; echo $?   # 0
    ! [ -a /tmp ]; echo $?   # 1
-c or -a; -f is regular file, which will always fail on a character device inode

Hi Stephen. This problem looks like libvirt bug to me: for some reason smm is not added to list of domains's features automatically. At the same time I don't know enough about secure boot support in Nova and may miss something. Could you take a look when you have time?

I took some time to analyze the background for this problems and would like to share my findings.

Secure boot support was added following BP https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/wallaby/implemented/allow-secure-boot-for-qemu-kvm-guests.html . Blueprint's description is very detailed and contains the points similar to what you have expressed: SMM should either be enabled manually or libvirt’s firmware auto-selection feature should add such capabilities. The domain XML syntax for firmware auto-selection seem to be [1].

A number of changes https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:bp/allow-secure-boot-for-qemu-kvm-guests were used to implement secure boot feature in nova. From patches it looks like developers only implemented second way (libvirt’s firmware auto-selection). So there was no option to manually define SMM, but firmware auto-selection should be enough to do the trick.

I also found that libvirt 6.0.0 had related problems (at least when it comes to RHEL https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1929357 ). So I think that first step here is to double-check which XML was passed from Nova to libvirt to confirm Nova or libvirt problem.


[1]
  <os firmware='efi'>
    <loader secure='yes'/>
  </os>

This is a good start. We need tests to prevent regressions though. There are a variety of tests in 'nova/tests/unit/virt/libvirt/test_driver.py' that you can build on (search for secure boot, e.g. 'test_get_guest_config_with_secure_boot_required'). Also, I have some comments on what's here

so technically this is just asserting that we dont request it and use the libvirt default if we have not enabel secure boot.

however its valid to enable SMM when not using secure boot in the future if we have a feature that requires it. so this might get droped in a future patch if that happens but for now its correct

My logic for this is in the code comments, I looked at what ovmf maintainers say about SMM and they said:

`this is supposed to be a security feature, and fallbacks are not allowed`

So the thinking is, if you enable SMM for security but aren't doing secure boot then unit test should bomb out, although the current code would actually allow that behaviour.

the SMM feature is not defiend by OVMF and predates its use for secure boot.
infact SMM can be used with bios boot without uefi or secure boot.

all vms created by libvirt 2.1.0+ by default should have SMM mode enable today.
in recent year the intoduction fo support for uefi and ovmf has complicated matters as usfi and secure boot also have depencices on SMM for the secure boot implemeation but it has other security uses so it not an error to enable it in general wehn not using secure boot.

This statement is flawed for the following reasons:

a) tsconfig SW_VERSION value is not a reliable indication that this version of the software is the active load. Please confirm with John Kung. The sure way to check is the software version of central cloud.

b) If both the system controller and the subcloud are running the same software version then this prestage request is not for upgrade. It's for reinstall. Hence is_upgrade flag should be false.

I think during system upgrade, as soon as the host is reinstalled with the new load, SW_VERSION will have new release id value but the system is not running that version as an "active" load until upgrade activation is complete. During this time system show will still show old software version.
confirming that on an upgrade, the software_version (in the subcloud) is not updated until after the upgrade-activate step is issued (in the subcloud).
After discussing with Tee, we now reject the prestage operation if the system controller is in an upgrading state. So we can now continue to use SW_VERSION as used here.

Good catch. This logic bug snuck in from my earlier testing.

From looking at tsconfig implementation in the config repo it is being parsed from /etc/build.info on the system controller. I'll run this by John.

I would think this operation is only allowed while the subcloud is in the "complete" status, or possibly "prestage failed" status for retry purposes, all the other statuses should not be allowed. Otherwise, the deploy_state will be messed up by running different operations simultaneously， and the result will be unpredictable and unrecoverable
Prestage rerun is acceptable. Prestaging packages will be skipped if it was done already. Prestaging images will be repeated as the user might have uploaded a new prestage images list.
Agreed. I have also allowed "prestage-complete" - I don't think there's an issue with re-running it here?

Based on the latest discussion with Matt and Scott, my understanding is the script will be accepting the <N+1_release_id> from the caller. Based on the provided release_id, it will search for the 2 files: <N+1_release_id>_package_list.txt and <N_release_id>_package_list.txt. The <N+1_release_id>_package_list.txt file should be available at some pre-defined location as part of the image.

The <N_release_id>_package_list.txt is retrieved from the subcloud by the caller and placed under:
/opt/platform/deploy/<N+1_release_id>/prestage/shared
beforehand.

utilities/platform-util/scripts/rpm-list.message: This script should be renamed to prepare-prestage-packages.sh

I don't think we need all of these parameters. The only user of this script (dcmanager) will provide the software version as the only input which is used to create and populate the shared prestage directory:

/opt/platform/deploy/<sw-version>/prestage/shared. 

The consumer of the content in this shared directory is the prestage_sw_packages playbook. It expects 2 sub-directories Packages and repodata and one file common_packages.txt under shared.

The Packages directory should contain only RPMs that need to be downloaded from the system controller. The repodata need to be regenerated based on the new RPMs and the common RPMs. Perhaps gen-bootloader-iso.sh can be updated to generate the required content for prestage shared directory and this script calls gen-bootloader-iso.sh with --prestage-data (or --shared-data-only) option.

Removed a lot of the parameters. We are down to just two now. 
However, it is not easy to call gen-bootloader-iso.sh within this script - it is easier to use only the relevant functionality to achieve our purpose.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: nit just to avoid confusion use "NUMA cell"
This is definitely a direction, one might want to optimize towards. But I'm not sure this is something we want by default to be the strategy. @Sean: what do you think?

Thank you for your comments, Balazs! Unfortunatelly I didn't get email notification about your comments, so I processed them with delay. (It could be the same situation with Sean :) ).

There are my suggestions about this problem:

For VMs without numa topology the situation will be the same (not worse). For VMs with one NUMA cell topology there will not be worse either. But for VMs with two NUMA cells we will improve situation. And we will DRAMATICALLY IMROVE situation with VMs with large number of NUMA cells. It affects public clouds very much, when most clients create VMs with as small as possible flavors to save the money. And when someone come even with medium flavor's VM with four NUMA cells on to hypervisor with four NUMA cells, and first NUMA cell crowded by small VMs - it got error. So we have hypervisor with 75% free resources and it isn't possible to place VM on it!

releasenotes/notes/extra-sorting-for-hos.message:
I think we need a lot more documentation than this. 
If I understand the code correctly then

1) with the default pack strategy: if CPU pinning is requested the the sorting always prefer more used pcpu than more used ram or more used pci dev. And there is no way to express that I want to pack by memory or by pci device.

2) with the default pack strategy: if CPU pinning is not requested the the sorting always prefer more used ram than more used pci dev. And there is no way to express that I want to pack by pci devices.

3) I think similar rules apply now to the spread strategy as well.

yes the confiration of ram vs disk vs cpus was intentionally not exposed to end users so we could potentally change that in the future.

we also consider this as a bug fix not a feature and wanted to keep the interface of its as minimal as possible.

yes simialr rules apply to both pack and spread. we did not really want to leak the implemation detail to endusers and treat this mroe like a hint then an api contract so that we can in the futrue evolve this byond the inital simpel sort to a cost based approch possibel with operator or user input.

Do we have a check for this in the libvirt driver? What happens if remote_managed is true for a device but the libvirt on the hypervisor is too old?

If Libvirt is older than the version with VPD support, the device XML will not contain this capability and, as a result, the device json dict will not contain VPD info even if the device has it.

There is no check currently and it will be treated as if VPD is not present.

I could think about how we could surface that better.

One thing I can do is making "supports_remote_managed_ports" capability host-dependent.

So besides the pre-filter checking for presence of remote-managed devices it will also depend on whether the Libvirt driver actually exposes this capability depending on the Libvirt version.

I think the original thinking that went into the `physical_network` tag was that a PCI device would always give you access to physical networks, however, this is not entirely true in the embedded switch port case where all traffic coming through it could be encapsulated with an overlay network header.

Likewise, there could be isolated sets of VTEPs which would not have the same VXLAN/GENEVE ranges much like there are isolated 0-4095 VLAN ranges on physically separate fabrics (i.e. VLAN 1 on physnet1 is a different broadcast domain from VLAN 1 on physnet2). I have not seen practical applications for that within a single cloud region though - typically all VTEPs in a single cloud region are expected to be able to reach each other over L3 and it is assumed that all VNIs are available via all VTEPs.

So I would probably spec out the alternative approaches to that just to be sure.

> have you tested this by the way. i would have assumed that when using bluefield 2 at least in DPU mode we would only have 1 vf and no representor netdev

So in the DPU mode you have 2 PFs for uplink ports (unless you enable NIC-side bonding in which case one PF can be hidden for the hypervisor. A PCI address will still be pre-allocated but only one PF will be there). On top of that you can enable SR-IOV and get VFs but no representors are visible to the hypervisor (they appear at the DPU side dynamically as the hypervisor host enables SR-IOV and sets num_vfs).

So, yes, for hw offload os-vif wouldn't be able to correlate VFs to representors because it doesn't see them at all.

config/puppet-modules/puppet-drbd-0.3.1/.message: This is testing that the disk is not connected (i.e. not reporting local/peer)?

This is testing if the disk has valid meta data.

The drbdadm man pages states: dstate: Show the current state of the backing storage devices. (local/peer)

So, if it has no valid meta data, then it will return error with the text "No valid meta data found" on the stderr. If it has valid data, then it will return success with a text on the stdout showing current state of the backing storage device local/peer.

The idea here is to not run the drbdadm create-md command if the DRBD has valid meta data, because this is causing the failure.

And neutron ovs flows pipeline are not circular, final actions are always output to ports or (NORMAL/flood) to ports. This flow final out ports are DVR router ports, and we can add qos policy to those ports.

All original flows with ``goto table 60`` will be changed to ``goto table 59``.

For packet from out side world to local VMs, it will change the physical vlan to local vlan here, and the final destinations are VM/router/X ports, so limit the ingress pps in next table 59.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
How about the following as a proposal to move forward with this. I suggest ironic-lib becomes agnostic to how operations get the required privileges to run. IPA can call them directly because it is root already. Other projects will need to wrap the functions in their own privsep context decorated functions, which will allow them to come up with their own privsep context policy (one very privileged context? fine grained?...)

For the ironic case I have a change which adds privsep[1]. We could build on that to wrap ironic-lib calls with ironic.privsep.* functions and contexts appropriate for the ironic service.

So actions for this plan could be:
- in ironic-lib functions, don't hardcode run_as_root=True ever. Add run_as_root to function arguments
- make changes to consuming projects to wrap required functions with their own privsep
- remove rootwrap.d/ironic-lib.filters entries whenever all consumers have moved over
- once all projects are handling their own privileges, deprecate and detach run_as_root arguments

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ironic/+/821363

In database's vnf table , the state of vnf is in "PENDING_HEAL" due to which "vnflcm op cancel" gives "vnf still in use" exception

There is problem in check_vnf_status_legality function in vnfm_db.py which raises exception for PENDING_HEAL due to which heal operation can not change from PROCESSING to FAILED_TEMP.

This line was added when the auto heal is implemented [1,2].

I suppose the purpose of this line is to prevent several consecutive heal requests triggered by the auto heal. 

To solve the problem you pointed out, we have two options: (i) deleting this line; (ii) treating `cancel` operation as an exception.

Which one do you think appropriate? or if you have another solution please kindly tell me. 


IMO, it's acceptable that deleting this line, i.e., (i), as the autoheal is a legacy implementation.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tacker/blame/0cd9cd8404c15440596bbb36ae00cb0e213ea84b/tacker/db/vnfm/vnfm_db.py#L521-L521
[2] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/tacker-specs/specs/stein/vdu-auto-healing.html#proposed-change

I think we should go with (ii)treating `cancel` operation as an exception.
as deleting this line can cause other issues.

Or can we differentiate call ( from where the call is coming if it is from cancel operation than no need to consider constants.PENDING_HEAL and work as per cancel operation otherwise work as usual)

Thank you for the review.

I did rebase and fixed an error regarding an error message [1].

Is this a distro-specific path? Can the rule file be discovered by greping for rule content instead?

Also maybe this would achieve the same thing:

  truncate -s 0 /etc/udev/rules.d/80-net-setup-link.rules

AFAIK /lib/udev/rules.d/80-net-setup-link.rules is not a distro-specific path, it was renamed from /lib/udev/rules.d/80-net-name-slot.rules in udev version 216, if I remember well, and you can find it in debian, fedora, gentoo, for example.
That udev rules file itself does not much, but it's the link between udev and systemd and triggers 99-default.link in /lib/systemd/network/
I thought about using truncate, or touch, I just wanted to keep the same scheme we used for other files here and give the chance for a customization if needed, adding rules inside udev-net-setup-link.rules.
I don't mind changing it if you think it's more suited in this case.

os_brick/initiator/connectors/nvmeof.py.message:
-1: Wouldn't this rescan have potential race conditions?

Let's say we have 3 volumes, vol1 and vol2 are connected to nova.

- Request disconnect vol1
- Request connect vol3

- Nova calls cinder to attach vol3 
- Nova calls os-brick to disconnect vol1 and completes that operation

- Nova calls os-brick to connect vol3 and the rescan is triggered
  The rescan brings back vol1 to the nova host

- Nova calls cinder to detach vol1
  We end up with a leftover device on the nova host

Scratch what I said about three volumes belonging to same controller :) - What I should have said is that vol3 should be on a controller that is already connected to the host too.

I think that another relevant point here is that nvme rescan also happens asynchronously even without explicitly calling 'nvme rescan'
If that is true, this should mean that the same possible race condition will happen with the old code too (though less commonly)

Also now that I'm looking at the old code, it does a rescan that seems unnecessary. (that whole "else:" statement seems unnecessary, but need to test that old code again to make sure) - I believe that rescan is what was causing other race conditions which we were seeing where errors were thrown due to 'nvme connect' calls with already connected controllers

Another big point here is that currently this code path does not do any 'nvme disconnect' at all - due to race conditions :) - it expects termination to happen on the backend - so this race condition will not happen here anyway

Overall thank you  I am going to refactor this patch - I think one thing that could help is adding '-D' to the 'nvme connect' command (for resolving the original issue this patch was addressing)
We believe this change is good as it is - especially because it solves a more harmful race condition that exists in the current code.

This is a very interesting scenario and I need to think it through more.

I'm pretty sure that overall you are right.

I think it is also worth mentioning that all three volumes should belong to the same controller (and hence target namespace).

The simplest thing that I can gather now is:

This race condition will be an issue only if the detach call to cinder doing terminate_connection will not cause a connection termination on the backend end.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Should we point xena backport instead ?
We probably should do a check at the very beginning, and ask for a confirmation. That's the proper way to inform a user.

No, a prompt is failure; we'd be checking the remote machines for the selinux status. If anything I could see the validations folks doing a check and returning the status but from an automation point of view halting a run and returning a prompt should be a non-starter.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Sorry - but no.

The right way is:
when:
  - ansible_facts.selinux is undefined
  - ansible_facts.selinux.status == "enabled"

Masking the issue like you're proposing is terrible, since it would mask issues caused by, say, failed openstack-selinux package install or the like (and YES, it happens).

This would be a way, but it is not the right way.

In this case with `ignore_errors`, which I generally dislike, would inform the user would by producing a failed but ignored notice at the end of the run and a big red notification during the run that SELinux was disabled; in my opinion, not being able to set an seboolean shouldn't be the cause of automation failure.

I can add the multiple condition but that will not raise any notification that SELinux is disabled; which I believe is a mistake, additionally, it would be a mistake to use a block/extra task to print a debug notice.

While I'm sure there are issues that have happened with `openstack-selinux` not being installed or in some failed state, this change would not have anything to do with that; every use of `seboolean` throughout THT is for the same basic context.

Still - I'd rather see a plain failure that's actually preventing things to move forward if selinux is enabled, and the sebool fails for #reason.
For instance, there are 2 booleans:
- virt_sandbox_use_netlink, coming from container-selinux
- os_enable_vtpm coming from openstack-selinux

Currently, there's a situation where container-selinux doesn't properly install, leading to a failure for openstack-selinux; so those booleans don't exist on the system.
If we're passing through without actually failing the deploy, it will lead to some really weird issues, and the operator will lose their mind, hairs and patience looking for the actual reason.

Note that, hopefully, the container-selinux will be updated accordingly in order to not fail anymore, but still, it's something that may happen, depending on what's going on with other packages.

"Silently" ignoring isn't good imho. But, in order to not completely block this review, I'll just push a "-1". And see how it goes forward with this proposal.

It's the decoded password that must contain a reasonably random array of bytes, without a few forbidden bytes because 1) mariadb cannot store password with \0 in a config file; and 2) sometimes we use passwords at the commadline, and this clashes a few other bytes, but only for mysql and clustercheck passwords.
All the openstack services connect to the DB via oslo.db, which can handle all bytes.

When OSA_DEPS_BRANCH moves from stable/ussuri to stable/victoria, Ansible moves from 2.9.x to 2.10, and some of the plugins and references may not work correctly. Since OSA_DEPS_BRANCH seems to be limited to the deploy node itself, leaving it at stable/ussuri while changing the branch to stable/victoria or beyond could work OK for now. TBD.

Existing MNAIO deployment is busted as best I can tell, at least with 18.04 hypervisor and ussuri or victoria. The playbooks are not really compatible with Ansible 2.10+, either, since module names are not collection-compatible.

With the changes here, one can deploy Ussuri on 18.04 VMs with the following:

Hypervisor: Ubuntu 20.04
export OSA_BRANCH="stable/ussuri"
export OSA_DEPS_BRANCH="stable/ussuri"
export DEFAULT_IMAGE="ubuntu-18.04-amd64"
export ENABLE_OSA_PROXY="false"
export MNAIO_ANSIBLE_PARAMETERS="-e mnaio_data_disk=nvme0n1 -e mnaio_data_disk_suffix=p1 -e osa_no_containers=true"
./build.sh

Or, you can deploy V/W/X with the following (Xena shown):

Hypervisor: Ubuntu 20.04
export OSA_BRANCH="stable/xena"
export OSA_DEPS_BRANCH="stable/ussuri"
export DEFAULT_IMAGE="ubuntu-20.04-amd64"
export ENABLE_OSA_PROXY="false"
export MNAIO_ANSIBLE_PARAMETERS="-e mnaio_data_disk=nvme0n1 -e mnaio_data_disk_suffix=p1 -e osa_no_containers=true"
./build.sh

(Take note of OSA_DEPS_BRANCH; it's important that remain at Ussuri to ensure Ansible 2.9.x is used for playbook compatibility). 

It would be nice to test and merge this as a stop-gap solution before modifying the playbooks for Ansible 2.10 compatibility. Let me know your thoughts.
Please ping us when it will be ready for reviews 😊

This is currently failing because EnablePublicTLS is default to True. We need to leverage the public_tls_enabled condition instead and validate the length is at least 64 chars. Something like this:

          - - name: Validate SSLCertificate is at least 64 chars when TLS is enabled
              when:
                - {if: [public_tls_enabled, true, false]}
              vars:
                ssl_cert: {get_param: SSLCertificate}
              block:
                - fail:
                    msg: >

                  when:
                    - ( ssl_cert | length ) < 64

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Can we not create a namespace automatically if STX_K8S_NAMESPACE is not specified?  ... e.g. automatically generate one derived from $USER and $PROJECT
I think we'll accept it as is, and we can explore our options in a follow-up update.

There will be use cases where the designer doesn't have privileges to create a namespace on a cluster. Do you think we should add it as an option? Just not sure if this should be on import-stx or stx-init-env as a parameter( --create-namespace)?

I would think automatically creating a namespace is the default behaviour.  And a cli argument or environment variable is required to override the default.

The question in my mind is, when the user supplies the namespae, what steps do we need to protect the namespaces of others?  Perhaps we require that $USER_ be found as a prefix of the name namespace?  Or _$USER as a postfix?  Or exclude namespaces that contain a prefix/postfix matching any other user id?

The reason I kept the namespace creation out of the script on this initial version is that this will depend on the k8s cluster you are connected.
You may have your own k8s cluster where creating namespaces are ok and you don't need to worry about authentication etc and you may be working in a multiuser environment where only admins can create/delete namespaces.

One of the ways we can lock namespace access to specific user is using k8s RBAC https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/access-authn-authz/authentication/
but this requires configuration on the cluster such as: creating user, setting up user kubeconfig with the certificates, creating the namespace and then creating a cluster role/binding to allow access to the namespace.

I'd wager most folks don't do that.

I see four minikube scenarios to cover a user with a pre-existing environment.  'repo sync' inside the container, 'git pull' to tools on the host, each with/without running a new 'import-stx' and 'stx-init-env'

Do any break? If yes, can we fix it (operate using the old setup), or gracefully detect the breakage and prompt the user on how to fix his environment.

You need to mention these tests in your commit message.

I created a new minikube env and built a couple packages to make sure everything was ok. After that, I applied this patch and was able to start the env (import-stx, stx-init-env) and build packages, the docker image tag was updated and the default values were set for STX_PLATFORM=minikube and STX_BUILD_CPUS.

I will test it out in an already setup minikube env but it would be good if others could also test. I tested with fresh environments and it worked on k8s and minikube. 

The differences will be the docker tag, STX_PLATFORM will default to minikube and if a user is setting MINIKUBECPUS it will need to be updated to STX_BUILD_CPUS.

When setting up the environment yes, but if you have the containers running you can just import-stx to load the stx tools into the PATH and then you can stx control start/status/stop/enter to manage the containers.

I tested on my local minikube and if I do a repo sync from the stx-builder container and apply this patch the current environment works and im able to run the utilities (build-pkgs, build-image, repo_manage etc). As I have a custom STX_BUILD_HOME on my env, I can stop this environment using stx control stop and then start it with either stx control start or stx-init-env and both are working.

The only issue if we keep the $project on the default path is that if a user is using the default STX_BUILD_HOME, after this patch merges the default will change and it will throw  an error or try to mount the host paths to /localdisk/user/project if the dir exists.

So, like I said on the other comment we can remove $project from the default STX_BUILD_HOME path to avoid this problem.

This concern applies to many of these changes, not just this one.

If the containers are already running/deployed it means they have STX_BUILD_HOME set (either manually or import-stx will set it to the default value: /localdisk/<user>)

Now, after adding $PROJECT into the default path value we may hit an issue when an user stops the containers and tries to start it with import-stx without exporting STX_BUILD_HOME first. 

As the default will add the project name to the path we will have the following error:

  ./stx-init-env
  The directory /localdisk/<user>/<project> desn't exist, please create it with the command:
  mkdir -p /localdisk/<user>/<project>
  Then execute this script again!

To avoid this we can remove the "project name" from the default path but if we are in a multiuser/multiproject environment we will need to export the STX_BUILD_HOME to the right directory before running the scripts

Which approach do you think it is best? Leave the default STX_BUILD_HOME as is so we don't break environments that rely on the default value or should we add the project now to the path and warn users of this change?
Ack

I wouldn't consider transitioning a pre-existing environment for minikube to k8s to be a requirement.  

Care is required however to ensure minikube and k8s use independent name spaces.

The main differences on the env vars are the following:

STX_PLATFORM=<minikube|kubernetes> - defaults to minikube.
STX_BUILD_CPUS=<X> - defaults to 6, replaces MINIKUBECPUS and it is used by build-pkgs for parallel jobs.
STX_BUILD_HOME=<host path> - root dir to the build, used by minikube and kubernetes.


Minikube:

STX_BUILD_HOME=/localdisk/<user>/

requires MINIKUBE_HOME, MINIKUBENAME, MINIKUBEMEMORY which are taken care by the import-stx script

* Minikube mounts STX_BUILD_HOME as /workspace internally

Host                               container      minikube
$STX_BUILD_HOME                    /               /workspace
$STX_BUILD_HOME/localdisk          /localdisk      /workspace/localdisk 
$STX_BUILD_HOME/aptly              /aptly          /workspace/aptly
$STX_BUILD_HOME/mirrors            /mirrors        /workspace/mirrors


Kubernetes:

To support multiple projects we can add $PROJECT (/localdisk/$USER/$PROJECT) to the path but if you set it
as we have on minikube it will also work as, for now, helm is mounting the volumes using hostpath similar 
to what it is doing on minikube.

Shared volumes are not yet supported on this update. Only single node cluster and host paths mount.

STX_BUILD_HOME=/localdisk/<user>/

STX_K8S_NAMESPACE=<namespace> - this will be the namespace where the pods are deployed


Host (K8s node)                    container 
$STX_BUILD_HOME                    /         
$STX_BUILD_HOME/localdisk          /localdisk
$STX_BUILD_HOME/aptly              /aptly    
$STX_BUILD_HOME/mirrors            /mirrors  


Inside the container the paths are all the same for K8S or minikube.

`NVMeOFConnector._get_nvme_controller(executor, nqn)` definition is getting renamed (prefix `_` removed because it is also used outside connector) and redefined to `get_nvme_controller(nqn)` (no executor param needed) in the nvmeof connection agent change https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/os-brick/+/802691

Sounds good.

I think we should merge this patch first, then I will rebase my patch, resolve merge conflicts, and update the _get_nvme_controller() call in your code.
thanks Zohar, yes we can synchronize the function name any way :)

Just a discussion note (not asking for changes,) is there a race condition possible here?

Could it happen that during a new volume connetion on the same nvme subsystem (especially by another process, such as between nova and cinder image copy) where it takes some time for the device to appear and be found, then this could trigger the same controller to be disconnected on line 423?

We ran into such issues with KumoScale, that is why we decided not to do `nvme disconnect` during `disconnect_volume()`

We also looked at doing it when there were zero (instead of one) devices left in the subsystem on `disconnect_volume()`, but that was also causing the same race condition.

As you mentioned, the "unpublish/unmap/unbind" on the storage system end is asynchronous to this code, so even with inter-process locking (which @lockutils.synchronized supposed to have such a feature, but it did not work for us) - there will still be a race problem.

yes, this is a good question. Volume disconnect happens not here but via "unmap/unbind" commands on storage system side. Here we try to disconnect a subsystem which is not really necessary, especially if it can be in race with other processes. May be it will be less harm to keep subsystem connection active.

not strictly your problem, but looking at the code coverage report, this function doesn't have coverage, and the two functions it calls don't have coverage either, and it's called by _wait_for_blk(), that also doesn't have any test coverage.  So you should look these all over carefully and add tests if you see anything weird or easily breakable in refactoring.

Its not good that each vendor invents its own property name for the volume UUID.
KIOXIA calls it vol_uuid, and here Dell added volume_nguid.
Core maintainers should decide on a single property for that.
This is a regression, _get_device_path has always returned a list with only the first item being returned in device_info previously. With this change now _all_ paths are returned.

doc/source/tenants.rst.message: Oh, thanks, I was remembering where our deployment in OpenDev explicitly triggered a scheduler reconfigure any time a new copy of the tenant config was deployed to the server, but I probably missed that becoming obsolete at some point. I didn't realize addition and removal of projects to tenants has started automatically triggering tenant reconfiguration, though it looks like our current playbook still runs a smart-reconfigure as a handler any time we update main.yaml.

We actually perform a smart reconfiguration event on startup of schedulers[1].  If there is a change to the tenant configuration (adding/removing projects/tenants), then those tenants should be reconfigured automatically.  However, if a change to in-repo zuul config was merged while all schedulers were offline, then a full or tenant reconfiguration would be needed in order for that to take effect.

It's not clear which thing you're trying to address here; if you have observed the first behavior in contradiction to what I wrote, we should look into that since it sounds like a bug.  If it's the second thing you want to communicate, then maybe we should elaborate a bit on this to make that clear.

So, just to be precise. The whole problem is that, at least for now, CentOS/RHEL 8 provided a few Python versions by default with meta-package that pointed also to the default one. It appears that for CentOS/RHEL 9 for now there is only one Python available.

I am not sure if it will stay that way, as RHEL 9 is currently a beta (https://blog.centos.org/2021/12/introducing-centos-stream-9/), but if so, this role ensure-python does not make sense with RPMs in future CentOS/RHEL systems.

charmcraft.yaml.message: Yes, this is intentional.  There is no 'hardening.yaml' file in the charm, and thus, the charm won't build with this in the charmcraft.yaml.  Essentially, originally it was a 'boilerplate' charmcraft.yaml that included things that the charm didn't actually have.  The charm doesn't build with it in, and thus won't get pushed to the charmhub.  Now with this patch (about building in the CI system), it also won't pass the Canonical CI; therefore, unbuildable charms won't get merged.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
When executing OpenStack CLIs for creating a new project or user directly from Ansible playbook fails due to missing authentication. In Patchset2 an Ansible task was created which obtain the admin authentication token and the same shell later execute OpenStack CLIs, but still, the CLIs failed due to missing authentication, refer to [1].

[1] https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/d61c0fe4d1c346d08c3730a6f65e935c/log/job-output.txt#107553

I have been reminded of some of the problems with pipeline property

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/104926

we should reconsider "just" using an `x-backend-user-agent` header set on all requests in the internal_client which the proxy app will look for and copy over in it's backend request helper.

I like how the proxy app has defined a "backend_user_agent" attribute that can be modified which it will use instead of forcing it to the getpid value

I think it would be cleaner to have the app default to the getpid value during worker init and then always use whatever backend_user_agent is set to at request time

I see two options how the internal client should override the app's backend_user_agent

1) use something like a pipeline property to find and set the proxy-app's backend_user_agent attribute
2) allow backend_user_agent to be set via config
3) something else?

maybe instead of pipeline property we should admit internal_client should always have direct explicit access to the instance of the proxy-app at the bottom of the pipeline and re-work swift.common.wsgi so that can bubble up out of something like:

self.app, self.proxy = loadapp_and_find_proxy()

thanks Matt

-1 for the lost user-agent in original client request headers, as discussed

Maybe, but 1. We are already using pipeline_property for InternalClient, so it's something we already are living with, so not changing any current risk levels.

And 2. always adding another backend-header seems like adding more to an internal rest api, sounds like an easy solution. But we're passing data in a request in the form of a header, that never indends to be sent out.. seems dirty.

But we have a mechanism that we already use 3 other times in the same class.. that sure has some brittleness (that we can fix in the future), that does exactly what we want.. talk/use a function further down the pipeline chain.

Thank you for the rebase!  I think the _final_pipeline_app is a good option compared to pipeline_property

You've made me reconsider my approach in unifying FakeInternalClient [1] - having a *real* InternalClient.__init__ that is passed in an app that's an instance of middleware_helpers.FakeSwift might be awesome!

I think the FakeApp and the user_agent property vs. app[._final_pipeline_app].backend_user_agent attribute both need some more justification - all other things equal less code (or more obvious code) is perferred.

1. https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/800701/8/test/unit/__init__.py#1016

I am not a big fan of screwing with members post-factum. But sadly, there aren't any arguments we can easily pass to proxy's Application(). The conf is loaded from the file, and that's it.

So, how about this alternative:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/825713

I'm really happy with this change overall - I don't think I understand some of the reservations that have been presented, and I don't want to minimize anyone's legitimate concerns...

... but I think the only thing we need to do before we merge is shore up the unittests.  We're connecting two modules (proxy's backend make-request, and internal client __init__) through an interface and we need to check BOTH sides (even if the proxy side is simple and obvious)

For bonus points we could try and find one of the tests in proxy.test_server that goes all the way from real proxy app to in-memory backend processes; but I'd be happy to just unittest generate headers uses the app's backend_user_agent attribute instead of the fixed os.getpid value
Oops, I forgot that we now have global_conf. Of course it's much better to use that. Add something like "user_agent" in there.

LGTM. I think I heard Alistair voice a concern at one point about this seeming at odds with the recent change for us to stop mucking with statsd prefixes -- but I think it's probably fine. The _property seems warning enough to keep us from mutating the backend user-agent mid-request-handling like we were doing with the statsd prefix. *Maybe* it'd be even better if we were twiddling self.app._pipeline_final_app._backend_user_agent?

I could imagine a reasonable way to get this plumbed in via global_conf, similar to what we did for log_name, but I *can't* think of a good reason that an *operator* would ever want to configure it, so it feels like a bit of an abuse.

swift/common/internal_client.py.message: this should probably remain, otherwise any middleware between client and proxy no longer has access to the user-agent value
to me the difference between _user_agent and user_agent attributes is not obvious

_user_agent is the private instance variable storing the value. And self.user_agent is a propety on the class (so uses of the InternalClient have the same API). using the property to set `self.user_agent = user_agent` will go set the private instance variable _and_ go and set the value down in the proxy.
I think we've mostly used pipeline_property (which I think Tim has pointed out is kind of gross and brittle) mostly for accessing attributes - not methods.
What about get_object_ring on line 161? That's a method. It just ends up being a local method that proxies down to the application/proxy sever class.
it's confusing to define a property who's name shadows and existing attribute

It doesn't shadow it anymore, the existing attribute is now self._user_agent.

It's using the same name, as it's a property. So accessing it is the same as accessing an attribute as before:

 self.user_agent = "fred"

will set self._user_agent to equal fred. But also allows us to call set_backend_user_agent at the same time. Meaning we don't change any of the InteralClient API for anything using it.

I think I'd find this change way more obvious if instead of the property stuff we just

   self.user_agent = self.app._pipeline_final_app.backend_user_agent = user_agent

I did have this for a while, but keeping it as a property meant same old internal client API and so didn't change the tests so much. Will change it though.

Done
i didn't realized we'd merged this `app or loadapp` change into ic already - this is great!

I wonder if we will regret that having taken the trouble to make the internal client user-agent distinct from the proxy, we now have no distinction between the client and backend user-agents

e.g. we won't be able to use only user-agent search for request from an internal client to backends, because the service->internal client request would have same user-agent.

i don't understand this distinction.  IIRC we had noted that proxy logging messages from ic daemons already included the "correct" user agent string; I originally thought it was just a bug that this user-agent wasn't carried forward to the backend requests!

But of course, I realized we don't expect client facing requests to the proxy to carry *their* user-agent to the backend storage servce (instead we get proxy-pid user-agent to a 1.conf server)

having templates that could interpolate swift.source sub-request codes or client user-agent or workflow-id could be powerful

ansible/roles/loadbalancer/templates/hap.message:
Sanity check whether this is a security hole.

This socket is unauthenticated and writable to the kolla group, and exposed via a bind mount:

haproxy_socket:/var/lib/kolla/haproxy/

The haproxy, keepalived and prometheus-haproxy-exporter containers have access to the same bind mount.

In theory this should be ok, but I'm wondering if it should be opt-in, behind a flag?

As per my bug, if I want to reboot a host for kernel upgrades or something and it's running API services fronted by HAProxy, is there already a kolla-ansible way of doing that with no downtime/not losing any requests?

I wouldn't assume that other services follow the same pattern as glance (they don't, in general). In fact, we don't even set glance_enable_rolling_upgrade to true by default, for reasons I forget.

We don't promise zero downtime upgrades, just low downtime rolling upgrades. Typically, we restart all containers of a given type at the same time. See the handlers.

What use case are you talking about? Restarting backends during rolling upgrades, or long-term removal of backends?

If there's something we should be doing with haproxy, shouldn't kolla-ansible automate it?

I see, sorry I hadn't read the bug report. There isn't currently a kolla-ansible native way to do that. We would stop the backend and accept the consequences.

I'm open to seeing a more complete solution in kolla-ansible. I'd be interested to see data on how bad it actually is to just stop the service though. We have a docker stop timeout of 60 seconds, which should allow most requests to complete. HAProxy should fail over to other backends once one goes down.

I largely agree with your assessment. The 42499 group is the kolla group in containers, and all users in the containers are in this group.

I think that while the risk here is low, I'd still rather see this behind a flag, given that it will not be used in most deployments.
Not used in most deployments? Do people just rip out backend servers and hope for the best?

I thought about this in my deployment but came to the conclusion that if you're able to get access to the docker host then you can do more damage in other ways.

On the host the socket is 0:42400 660. So you have to be root or be in the gid 42400 which isn't even a group on my host... 

Just checked now and the whole of /var/lib/docker is 710 root:root so you can't even see it unless you are already root.

I just read over how Kolla does glance rolling upgrades (https://github.com/openstack/kolla-ansible/blob/stable/wallaby/ansible/roles/glance/tasks/rolling_upgrade.yml) and I'm making the assumption it's the same for other services.

It looks like as you said, containers just get killed. There's no real way of tracking or knowing if what state things truly are in. That wouldn't be acceptable in my use case, good to know for me that 0 downtime upgrades aren't error free downtime and by some definitions not 0 downtime.

I'll add the flag as you requested, and if I come up with something that integrates with the Kolla rolling-upgrades stuff I see if I can upstream it.

Thanks, that's good to know 😊

Pushed up the changes you requested in PS3.

etc/memcache.conf-sample.message:
I wonder if it'd be easier to reason about if the config option was something like

 item_size_warning_threshold

that seems odd to me, vs -1 -> unlimited i.e. warnings disabled
OK. So what do you think, -1 is disabled 0 is everything is logged?
but only once i.e. auto does not track changes to memcache configs until the swift service is restarted

Oh interesting point. We could check everytime but that might be a little too much extra load. And AFAICT there isn't an easy way to re-load based on a timer withougt changes to the wsgi server code... unless I'm missing something obvious.

given that 80 is an arbitrary choice, do we really want to start firing warning on potentially very healthy clusters after upgrade, rather than defaulting to 'off'.

Also, how does an op switch this off without having to go and lookup memcache config: I think I'd need to know the item_size_max, hope it is consistent across memcache, and also set the threshold to 100.

I'm not sure the current behaviour of item_size_warning_threshold=0 causing the warnings to be disabled is  intuitive. item_size_warning_threshold=-1 -> unlimited would be intuitive but is probably disallowed because it's a percent option.

I might suggest KISS: just support an absolute warning threshold that can be -1 to disable.

oh ok. So to KISS, we just have a item_size_warning_threshold which isn't a percentage. But an absolute size. But it seems in this case we loose the advantage of the auto lookup, now you need to keep an eye on the max_item_size anyway to figure out when you want it triggered.

so if I (perversely) want to get warnings for everything I might like to set this to zero, but that actually disables the warnings

glance/api/v2/router.py.message: I'm confused about this. Is this dead code? Won't the above two rules match both things that would have been rejected here?

It's "allowed_methods" as in ignore list rather than catch list, it picks up everything else. Any other method, like POST or PUT will be mapped to reject. Just like the '/info/' endpoints above has only 'GET' methods allowed and anything else gets mapped to the reject.

If you look through the API mapper, all endpoints are filtered like that to reject anything that is not defined. There was some good reson in the wsgi router implementation why this was the way to go.
Same here, so I'm assuming it's expected. Can you explain why we need this, just so I know?

Why do this? IMHO, this is really bad behavior for an API to have whole URLs that appear and disappear based on the configuration. Why would we not make the endpoints just return a proper 4xx code for "caching not enabled" like 405 (Method Not Allowed) or 409 (Conflict)?

It would simplify this code, make this all better behaved, IMHO and be in line with what we do elsewhere. For example, delete from store always exists, but refuses politely if not enabled_backends:

https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/api/v2/images.py#L726

Now, that's a little different because it's returning a 404, but that is because it's a named resource handler, and that really doesn't exist if backends is disabled, but the API itself is still there.

Here's another example. The operator can disable all their import methods (and they do), yet the import call doesn't become a 404, it just always returns "sorry I'm not configured to do that thing":

https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/api/v2/images.py#L1527

More data in the openstack api guidelines around API extensions:

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/extensions.html

This says "Having different URLs in a service, based on different drivers, breaks interoperability" and I think that generally applies here to a thing being present or absent if the "cache driver" is enabled. It does say that URL differences must be discoverable, but only if those differences are not avoidable. This is quite avoidable I think.

It's not about holding the patch hostage or anything else, I think what he is suggesting here is why should we mark this as EXPERIMENTAL is there any strong reason for doing it, or its just a practice we use to follow?

If it is straightforward and simple change then why we should flag it experimental then next release revisit it and make it supportive?

> Why do this? 

I think you answered your own question in your comment in the router. Consistency. Every 'EXPERIMENTAL' API version we have introduced into the Images API v2 has had to have a way to turn it off. Should we start the conversation of how good or bad practise it is now, is fine by me, but holding this patch hostage during that conversation will just mean that the feature will not be included in the Xena release.

glance/api/versions.py.message:
I see that this is a pattern for glance, but I think it's a bad one. Making the API change so much based on the config is confusing for clients and users, IMHO (see comment on the previous file). Further, if I've got caching enabled and backends disabled, I've got a weird gap in the exposed versions that would be confusing, even though all of the behaviors that those versions represent are in the actual code.

I found that 2.10 is apparently the delete from store api, but I had a hard time finding docs for what the other ones in the conditional below even mean. I didn't see a lot of stuff being swapped out of the router based on config there, so I'm guessing that those too are basically enabled all the time, which makes the conditional below also inconsistent.

Also, why is this experimental? It's extremely simple, we're proposing putting it into the glance client, which means people are going to start using it and we'll just break them if we have to change it. If we've got it in the client, it works and is tested, why not just roll forward and iterate if we need to?

> Also, why is this experimental?

Just like we have specs for silly small things we have the tradition to roll in new API endpoints in as 'EXPERIMENTAL' for the initial release as specified in the spec. 

>It's extremely simple, we're proposing putting it into the glance client, which means people are going to start using it and we'll just break them if we have to change it. If we've got it in the client, it works and is tested, why not just roll forward and iterate if we need to?

Like you pointed out in the comments on the functional tests, the fact that the test happens to pass while it's ran does not mean that the feature works as intended and will keep operating such way. We might have missed something critical that gets noticed only in actual use. Thus having the buffer to be able to change the bahaviour without breaking the stable API promise (any user using it and breaking because it changed is aware for the possibility as they were using experimental feature). Inconvenient, for sure, yet still better option than being stuck with bad behaviour just because we were over confident to announce it stable from the get go.
And I think here exactly tempest comes into picture to make sure that without mocking anything our feature is actually working as per expectation.

I really don't understand the motivation behind this logic of only saying the latest thing is current if it's enabled by config. A thing can be supported and disabled - the latter really has nothing to do with the former.
Probably we should revisit this in upcoming PTG.

Nope, this tests all and only the new functions of CacheController.
ImageCache is mocked on L33 and overriden to be used in L35. L37-39 creates the ImageCache mocked functions named on the first element of the input list, CSV of the ImageCache function names we expect the cache controller to call. These functions are not altered, so testing them as part of this change would just introduce redundancy.
The second element is the function to be tested picked from the actual controller object (L40) which has only the cache and _enforce mocked, so all of it's controller functions executed are the actual code we are testing.
Third element is the new policy rule which we ensure gets passed to (L46) the mocked (L32) _enforce after the tested function is called (L45). args being a list passed as positional arguments to the test call makes sure the needed arguments are passed (extra or missing elements in this list would cause syntax fault as all input parameters are defined).
L47-55 ensures that we called those ImageCache functions with correct parameters when applicable (the UUID1 which is the last element of this list as well as the queue test L75-79).
Finally on L56 we make sure we did not miss any calls to the ImageCache, or in other words all the calls to it were accounted for in the verification above.
I would put these as decorators on this method, or move the body into a second-level helper just to keep the indenting down.

This is all pretty hard to follow and fairly obscure. I'm not sure it's really saving much in terms of code to have this all squashed together and it's definitely not making it easier to read. Can't this be unwound a bit, even if it means largely just duplicating some work in the actual tests?
I didn't see any response to my prior comment about this, so I'll just say again: I think this is convoluted and hard to follow and should be cleaned up.
